data.title: The Films of Lee Chang-dong: Dignity for the Downtrodden
data.meta_description: The Korean director's work centers on people whom society deems unworthy. He believes they don't deserve to be easily discarded.
data.text:
Early in Lee Chang-dong’s Oasis (2002), the main character Jong-du (Sul Kyung-gu) recklessly rides a motorbike on a highway. He speeds in and out of lanes, unfazed by the potential danger, like a feral wildcat in the jungle.

By now, we know enough about Jong-du to be anxious. He was just released from prison for manslaughter, the result of a hit-and-run accident, and before then, he was convicted of assault and attempted rape. He’s estranged from his family, who changed addresses during his two-and-a-half-year prison stint and didn’t bother to tell him. His more successful older brother Jong-il (Ahn Nae-sang) is endlessly frustrated that Jong-du can’t get his act together. At this moment, we understand why.

Jong-du moves through the streets recklessly and suddenly approaches a movie production. The handsome actor sits in a fancy car as a camera crew records him on one of those large production trucks attached in the front. Without missing a beat, Jong-du interrupts the shot, asking the crew if they are making a movie and then taunting the actor by saying he, too, can pretend to drive…
